Consolidation Shearing Properties of Soi.description: Theoretical and experimental studies of the consolidation and shearing properties of both saturated and unsaturated soils.

Soil and Rock Dynamics.description: Wave propagation in soil and rock, foundation vibration and isolation, dynamic behavior of soil.

Advanced Soil and Rock Dynamics.description: Advanced topics in soil and rock dynamics.

Decision, Risk, and Reliability.description: Principles and theory for modeling uncertainty in civil engineering, analyzing how uncertainties affect performance, and developing rational bases for design and decision making under uncertain conditions.

Advanced Analysis of Geotechnical Engine.description: Development and application of linear and nonlinear finite element procedures for solution of geotechnical engineering problems related to embankments, excavations, static soil-structure interaction, and seepage.

In-Situ Soil Characterization.description: This course will focus on in-situ investigations performed for the purpose of collecting detailed site characterization data for direct and/or indirect use in geotechnical design. Specifically, we will study various static (e.g., SPT, CPT, VST, DMT, PMT) and dynamic (e.g., CHT, DHT, SW) in-situ tests used to obtain estimates of stratigraphy, density, strength, stress history, modulus, and permeability of geotechnical materials.

Geotechnical Earthquake Engineering.description: Application of soil dynamics to earthquake engineering; influence of soil conditions on ground motion characteristics; evaluation of site response using wave propagation techniques; liquefaction of soils; liquefaction mitigation; seismic response of earth structures; seismic slope stability.

Foundation Engineering.description: Bearing capacity, design of piers and pile foundations.

Earth Retaining Structures.description: Types of earth retaining systems, earth pressure theory; gravity, semi-gravity, and modular walls; reinforcing elements; mechanically stabilized earth walls and reinforced soil slopes; soil nail walls; sheet pile walls, drilled shaft walls and anchored walls; advances in soil reinforcement.

Geoenvironmental Engineering.description: Hydraulic conductivity of soils; clay behavior; compacted clay barriers; unsaturated soil behavior and barriers; geosynthetics and geosynthetic barriers; contaminants and solid waste; liquid drainage layers; stability of landfills; contaminant transport through barriers.

Engineering Geology.description: Fundamental concepts of geology, including geologic time and plate tectonics. Interactions among earth materials, landforms, and geologic processes across a range of spatial and temporal scales. Emphasizes common interests shared by engineers and geologists, as well as gaps between the disciplines, such as those posed by the geologic vocabulary.

Stability of Earth Slopes.description: Development and application of limit equilibrium procedures, including effects of seepage, rapid drawdown, and seismic loading and reinforcement for stability analysis of natural and constructed slopes.

The Finite Element Method.description: Introductory concepts; weighted residual methods; strong and weak forms;boundary conditions; global v. local basis functions; error estimates; smooth and nonsmooth problems; one-dimensional second- and fourth-order problems; two-dimensional potential and plate problems; two-dimensional and three-dimensional elasticity; dynamic and eigenvalue problems; numerical, computational, and meshing issues; applications using commercial software.

Dynamics Response of Structures.description: Single and multidegree-of-freedom systems; dynamic load factors, response to harmonic excitation; damping; modal analysis; direct integration of equations of motion; analysis in time and frequency domains; application to earthquake, wind, wave, and traffic loadings.

Earthquake Engineering.description: Earthquake characteristics; seismic loads; elastic and inelastic response; analysis and design of buildings for earthquakes.

Computer Methods in Structural Analysis.description: Linear and nonlinear analysis of trusses and frames; introduction to structural stability; and computational aspects of linear and nonlinear structural analysis.

Design and Perf of Pavements.description: Pavement performance evaluation and the application of theory to the design of pavements.

Bituminous Materials.description: Design and use of asphalt mixtures; chemical, physical, and rheological properties of asphalt; and practical applications in highways, airports, and other construction.

Advanced Geomechanics.description: Recent literature on petroleum production practice and petroleum and geosystems engineering problems.

Advanced Reservoir Engineering.description: Basic concepts of reservoir engineering, with applications to the production of hydrocarbons from both gas and oil reservoirs. Examines the governing equations for flow in permeable media, as well as conceptssuch as streamline flow; pseudo-steady-state flow, fractional flow, and both immiscible and miscible flow. Uses black oil and compositional reservoir simulators.

Finite Element Methods.description: Recent literature on petroleum production practice and petroleum and geosystems engineering problems.

Advanced Structural Geology.description: Origin of earth structures, solution of advanced structural problems, newest techniques, field techniques, and field problems.

Seismology 2.description: Basic seismology theory and its application to the study of the interior of the Earth (crust, mantle, and core), earthquakes, and plate tectonics.

Computational Methods in Geoscience.description: A survey of geophysical data analysis methods, with a focus on time series, including sampling and aliasing, convolution and correlation, statistics, linear digital filters, properties and applications of the discrete Fourier transform, and least squares. Instruction in MATLAB andFortran and solution of data analysis problems using these two languages.

Inverse Theory.description: Vector spaces; model parameter estimation methods from inaccurate, insufficient, and inadequate measurements; linear, quasi-linear, and highly non-linear problems; local and global optimization methods. Emphasis on practical problem solving.

Geomorphology Process & Form.description: Explores how Earth surface processes combine to shape landscapes through erosion and deposition. Emphasis on open channel flow, sediment transport, fluvial and hillslope processes, and tectonic controls on landscape evolution.

Seismology 1.description: Seismic, gravity, magnetic, electrical, and electromagnetic methods of exploration for petroleum and minerals.

Seismic Imaging.description: Seismic reflection imaging for visualizing the interior of Earth's upper crust. Study of fundamental imaging concepts from a unified geometrical point of view. Hands-on practical experience with imaging seismic data in an open-source software environment.

Modeling flow and transport through poro.description: Modeling flow and transport through porous media.

Crustal Geofluids.description: Designed to provide a technical foundation for exploring how fluids drive fundamental geologic processes in sedimentary basins. Includes characterizing pressure and stress in sedimentary basins, exploring the origin of overpressure through theory and characterization, and examining how pressure and stress couple. Problems include how sedimentation generates overpressure, how hydrocarbons are trapped in the subsurface, how mud volcanoes form, how submarine landslides are generated, and the origin of methane hydrates.

Statistical Methods 1.description: Introduction to the fundamental concepts and methods of statistics. Includes descriptive statistics, sampling distributions, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing. May include simple and multiple linear regression, analysis of variance, and categorical analysis. Use of statistical software is emphasized.

Statistical Methods 2.description: Continuation of Statistics and Data Sciences 380C (or Statistics and Scientific Computation 380C). Surveys advanced statistical modeling and may include random and mixed effects models, time series analysis, survival analysis, Bayesian methods, and multivariate analysis of variance. Use of statistical software is emphasized.

Monte Carlo Methods in Stats.description: Stochastic simulation for Bayesian inference, designed to develop an understanding of Markov chair Monte Carlo methods and their underlying theoretical framework. Topics include Markov chains, Monte Carlo integration, Gibbs sampler, Metropolis-Hastings algorithms, slice sampling, and sequential Monte Carlo.

Bootstrap Statistics.description: Concepts of probability and mathematical statistics with applications in data analysis and research.

Regression Analysis.description: Concepts of probability and mathematical statistics with applications in data analysis and research. Simple and multiple linear regression, inference in regression, prediction of new observations, diagnosis and remedial measures, transformations, and model building. Emphasis on both understanding the theory and applying theory to analyze data.

Intro Scientific Programming.description: Introduction to programming using both the C and Fortran (95/2003) languages, with applications to basic scientific problems. Covers common data types and structures, control structures, algorithms, performance measurement, and interoperability.

Solid Mechanics 1.description: Mathematical description of stress, deformation, and constitutive equations of solid mechanics; boundary value problems of elasticity.

Solid Mechanics 2.description: Continuation of Engineering Mechanics 388. Additional topics in elasticity, plasticity, viscoelasticity, variational methods, and other areas of solid mechanics.

Advanced Theory of Finite Element Method.description: Contemporary topics in the theory and application of finite element methods.

Wave Propagation 1.description: Solutions of linear wave equations; waves in elastic media, including plates and cylinders; transient waves, transform methods, asymptotic approximation.

Acoustics 1.description: Plane waves in fluids; transient and steady-state reflection and transmission; lumped elements; refraction; strings, membranes, and rooms; horns; ray acoustics; absorption and dispersion.

Acoustics 2.description: Spherical and cylindrical waves, radiation and scattering, multipole expansions, Green's functions, waveguides, sound beams, Fourier acoustics, Kirchhoff theory of diffraction, and arrays.

Wave Phenomena.description: Fourier acoustics and angular spectra; nearfield acoustical holography; Fraunhofer, Fresnel, and parabolic approximations; sound beams; Green's functions; Born approximation; propagation and scattering in moving, periodic, and random media.

Electromechanical Transducers.description: Modeling, analysis, and design of transducers for reception and transmission of acoustic and vibration signals; dynamics of coupled electrical, mechanical, and acoustical systems; and the effects of transducer characteristics on fidelity and efficiency of transduction.
